Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: An immersive gaze-controlled video game to help children on the autism spectrum improve their eye contact, emotion recognition, and joint attention skills
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to improve the way educators and therapists teach social skills to children who are on the autism spectrum (as well as those affected by other social skills disorders) and deliver cost efficiencies that could expand access to such support across diverse socioeconomic classes and geographical regions. These advances have potential to produce meaningful quality-of-life improvements for these children in areas such as employability, educational attainment, and personal relationships. Given that there are ~900K children on the spectrum in the US alone, and that the rate of diagnosis has been rising in recent years, the technology has significant potential for impact. It also has significant commercial potential: the US special education and therapy market is estimated at over 8 billion dollars, and feedback from therapists and educators has indicated significant commercial demand for a product like this. In addition, by pushing the frontiers of video game-based training by incorporating real-time eye tracking data, the proposed project will expand scientific and technological understanding of how video games can be used to shape human behavior.


The proposed project involves furthering the development and evaluation of a video game designed to help children on the autism spectrum improve their social skills?a significant and growing need. Key development activities include (1) adding multiple types of gaze-controlled social skill training exercises, namely those targeting emotion recognition and joint attention; (2) incorporating a low-cost, consumer-grade eye tracker; (3) building an automated feedback system to ensure proper player positioning relative to the eye tracker; and (4) refining adaptive algorithms to personalize game difficulty and maximize engagement. These features will be designed and implemented by a diverse team with expertise in video game development, autism research, and technology commercialization. Evaluation will consist of tracking performance against quantitatively measurable success metrics related to game playability and engagement via human subject research across 10 participants (50 gameplay sessions). The expected result is a video game that addresses multiple social skill deficits, engages the target demographic, and can be deployed by therapists, educators, and parents in a cost-effective manner.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, BioStream Technologies, LLC (BioStream) aimed to establish the commercial feasibility of its immersive 3D video game-based training tool which combines integrated eye tracking technology with instructional principles used in applied behavior analysis (ABA) to improve core social skills deficits in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). This condition affects 1 in 59 children in the US and many more worldwide. The company partnered with the Center for Autism Research at The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) on this project.

ASD is characterized in part by difficulty in social interaction and communication, which can affect employability, educational achievement, and quality of interpersonal relationships. Driving improvement in social skills deficits can be especially challenging for therapists and educators yet there is an underutilization of technology to help. BioStream's patent pending technology applies proprietary algorithms to real time eye tracking data to seamlessly, precisely, and intelligently adapt training during gameplay based on each individual child's performance over time. The game enables children to practice social skills, such as making eye contact and recognizing others' emotions, in a comfortable environment before applying them in daily life.

During this project, 16 children with ASD engaged in 76 gameplay sessions at CHOP with each session lasting approximately 45 to 60 minutes. Multiple and diverse commercialization feasibility parameters were measured during the course of each session and subsequently analyzed.

The results of this research demonstrated that BioStream's training tool, which integrates a low-cost eye tracker, consistently deployed adaptive exercises targeting emotion recognition, eye contact, and joint attention while maintaining child engagement and without requiring active supervision. In doing so, BioStream successfully established the feasibility of commercializing its video game-based training tool under the metrics set forth in its NSF proposal.

In addition, real world social skills assessments were administered by CHOP as part of the research conducted during this project. These assessments produced encouraging preliminary data on the ability of BioStream's novel and patent-pending technology to produce improvement in eye contact and emotion recognition in children with ASD while also maintaining positive child engagement.
